raw_text: We use a phrase-based system similar to Moses (Koehn et al, 2007) based on a set of common features including maximum likelihood estimates p ML (e|f) and p ML (f |e), lexically weighted estimates p LW (e|f) and p LW (f |e), word and phrase-penalties, a hierarchical reordering model (Galley and Manning, 2008), a linear distortion feature, and a modified KneserNey language model trained on the target-side of the parallel data
clean_text: We use a phrase-based system similar to Moses (Koehn et al, 2007) based on a set of common features including maximum likelihood estimates p ML (e|f) and p ML (f |e), lexically weighted estimates p LW (e|f) and p LW (f |e), word and phrase-penalties, a hierarchical reordering model (Galley and Manning, 2008), a linear distortion feature, and a modified KneserNey language model trained on the target-side of the parallel data.

raw_text: The phrase-based reordering model (Tillmann, 2004) determines the presence of the adjacent bilingual phrase located in position (s? 1 ,v+1) and then treats the orientation of bp as S. Given no constraint on maximum phrase length, the hierarchical phrase reordering model (Galley and Manning, 2008) also analyzes the adjacent bilingual phrases for bp and identifies its orientation as S.However, given a bilingual phrase, the above mentioned models just consider the presence of an adjacent bilingual phrase rather than the number of adjacent bilingual phrases
